options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Module 1: MRI concepts, Module 2: Machine learning & image analysis, Module 3: Cell-biomaterial interactions

We studied Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectroscopy and Imaging, Image Processing/Analysis and Machine Learning, and Biomaterial-cell interactions. I learned processing/analysis in MATLAB, wet lab techniques, and new understandings of the aforementioned topics.

Knowledge: Lots about BME lab techniques, more information about NMR and its applications, how to process and manipulate images in MATLAB, how to create and characterize nanoparticles, etc.

Skills: lots of MATLAB, and how to write 10 page reports.

Insights: Biomedical engineering is very broad. Each module focused on a very different aspect of BME lab work. Also, it reaffirmed how in courses with multiple professors, it shouldn't come as a surprise that some modules will be better than others
I gained understanding of the use of NMR, how to process images and train machine learning networks and how nanoparticles are made and optimized for drug delivery.
lab skills

- Imaging and MRI 
- Image analysis and machine / deep learning for image enhancement and segmentation
- nanoparticle (NP) synthesis, Cell culture, NP-cell and NP characterization

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really didn't like being fully remote and just watching people do experiments in Module 1; although professor was nice, we were basically staring at a screen the whole time. Module 2 was really nice in that we worked together to do the lab and code; I thought some parts were a bit repetitive, but I liked being able to apply machine learning & report content was fair. In module 3, I loved being able to do in-person work, even if it was only for 1/4 weeks, and it was much better than all going in at once and doing experiments.

The course did a great job of transitioning to a remote-friendly format. With the ability to have one team member in person and the rest virtual, we were still able to collaborate while completing the experiments.

Strengths: In-person component for Module 3! In a semester that was entirely remote, it was nice to be able to come into the lab and create nanoparticles. Module 3 was the most enjoyable module personally, for this reason.

Weaknesses: Why does BME use so much MATLAB? There was literally an entire module dedicated to MATLAB. That's just something you'll have to deal with though. Also, Module 1 was very passive, as we were watching a bad-quality movie of experiments most of the time, and sometimes they were hard to follow. Luckily, a lot of background information was provided in order to help us better understand the logistics of it.
the virtual lab in groups was great as we were able to follow the student in the lab and contribute to what was being done.

Strength: The material from Module 1, 2, and 3 are very interesting and applicable. I liked the short form format of module #2. 
Weakness: The lab report instructions could be improved by being more specific and either allow a larger page limit or reduce the amount of written requirements to fit the 8 page limit. It was difficult to see (through Zoom) what was happening in Module 1 due to poor camera and audio quality.
This class was very difficult over zoom and not engaging.

The style of teaching and the format of the three module is very different. For the first module, the assignment was supposed to be a 8 page lab report, but everyone ended up with around 30 pages because of the amount of images we needed to include. We also did not receive the grade for the first lab report until the completion of module 2.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All seemed good. Wish there was more Module 1 engagement.

In the NMR module, we mainly had to watch the professor on Zoom complete the experiment with the help of two students (due to space restrictions). The professor kept it very engaging and helped explain what was happening at each step. In the image analysis module, the work was completed in MATLAB, so screen share and breakout rooms in Zoom made that module easily adaptable to the virtual format. In the biomaterial-cell interactions module, one lab member went in at a time while the rest were virtual on zoom, so we were still able to collaborate.

In-person component for Module 3 was great! I was lucky in that I ended up going into the lab three times, so I feel I gained a very thorough understanding of the lab material compared to if I had just been remote the whole time. 

Module 2 was nice in that it reaffirmed that in order to free up space in the in-person lab, maybe an entirely MATLAB-based experiment can be done remotely.

Module 1 needed drastic improvement to optimize the course for remote learning. The computers in the TAC NMR lab were very old and did not have zoom, so we could not see anything on the screens clearly. New computer installation would be very beneficial.

It was hard to contribute to the lab remotely (particularly for the nanoparticle lab). Normally the camera is pointed in some weird direction and so you can't really partake in the lab. I think this hindered my learning. I wish members of a lab group could have all been there at the same time so we could all learn the techniques.
module 1 was very tough to be engaged with virtually

Practices that succeeded: The lab reports helped me process what was being done through the weeks.
Practices to be improved: The classes were really great, but for Module 1, it was very difficult to hear and see what was happening in lab through Zoom simply due to poor audio quality and low resolution / lag for video.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes -- must take if BME; generally useful information to be in this field. It was definitely more work than expected but nothing that was unhandleable.
Yes, I'd recommend it to anyone interested in learning hands-on about NMR, image analysis in MATLAB, or Biomaterial-cell interactions.
It's mostly a BME major requirement. Module 3 was great, but unless you are extremely passionate about NMR and MATLAB Image Processing, then I don't know if it is worth it.
Yes, I liked the material that was taught! Super interesting and relevant to the machine learning that I want to explore for Senior Project

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: remote lab
Remote lecture for Module 1; interactive lab online for module 2; in person and virtual for module 3
I learned remotely for the entire semester, so the lab was completely virtual for me. I had lab partners in person who would go in-person for portions of the lab experiments.

Module 1: entirely lecture-based virtual lab
Module 2: entirely interactive remote lab
Module 3: in-person lab
Virtual lab + in-person lab
Also some in-person labs
there was also a virtual prelab lecture before practical work began
Combination of in-person and virtual lab with recorded lectures.
mix of in person and live virtual
One in person lab
In-person (for on-campus students) / virtual (for off-campus students)
Mix of virtual and in-person lab modules
Mix of in-person and virtual lab
